Begin story:

Paul Pierce: Staying Connected to the NBA

Camped out in his Los Angeles home, Paul Pierce's television is frequently programmed to NBA games. While some retired players turn away from the sport that once commanded their lives, Pierce has stayed attuned to the league he played in for 19 seasons, hosting friends for marquee matchups and ordering piles of chicken wings.

“I put in a big order because we usually got friends over, and we're watching some hoops,” Pierce said with a laugh.

But Pierce's love for basketball goes beyond just watching games on TV. He has remained an active participant in the basketball community, attending events and supporting various organizations.

Next week, Pierce will head to Houston for the first round of the NCAA tournament, watching games from inside a Buffalo Wild Wings alongside "All The Smoke" podcast hosts Stephen Jackson and Matt Barnes, plus two-time WNBA MVP A'Ja Wilson as part of an activation experience labeled "BnB-Dubs."

He has also partnered with Showtime Basketball after a run with ESPN, continuing his involvement in the sport he loves.

And with so much consternation from plenty of Pierce's fellow former players, taking to national broadcast and podcast platforms to lament certain elements of present-day NBA, a conversation with the Hall of Fame swingman was the perfect opportunity to better understand why so many of Pierce's brethren are willing to voice criticisms of the league they once inhabited.

"It’s been happening for a while, but it seems like it's reached a fever pitch now where there are so many former players sitting at desks across the national networks and there are so many podcasts such as yours," Pierce said.

"There’s a difference between older players telling you that behind the scenes and Charles (Barkley) being on national TV and everyone kind of airing out dirty laundry on podcasts.”

Despite the criticism, Pierce has remained optimistic about the league's future, pointing to the talent of players like Giannis Antetokounmpo and Jayson Tatum, who he sees as potential stars for years to come.

And while some fans may criticize the league's use of load management or other policies, Pierce believes that fans will continue to tune in regardless.

"When you have all these prominent voices killing the product, it creates this discourse online that things for the league aren’t going well," Pierce said. "But the NBA has always survived regardless of the different dynamics that have come up over the years. So it sparks interest either way."

As Pierce continues to stay connected to the sport he loves, he hopes that others will find ways to remain involved and engaged, no matter how many years have passed since they last played.

"They've taken that maturity leap to finally take that next step and possibly be together for a long time and win multiple championships if healthy," Pierce said of the Phoenix Suns, who he sees as one of the most promising teams in the league.

With his passion for the game still burning bright, there is no doubt that Pierce will continue to be a familiar face in the basketball community for years to come.
